choices.text: Left sided aortic arch is seen
Sub pulmonic stenosis determines the severity
Multiple ventricular septal defects may be seen

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother, who is concerned about his poor feeding and blue-tinged skin, particularly during crying. Upon physical examination, the pediatrician notes a harsh pan systolic murmur at the upper sternal border. The infant's growth parameters are below the third percentile for his age. A chest X-ray is ordered, which is as shown below All of the following are true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never associated with DiGeorge syndrome

 

Option B:


Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that can sometimes be associated with genetic syndromes such as DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome), which can present with a range of anomalies including conotruncal heart defects like TOF. Therefore, option B is not true as TOF can indeed be associated with DiGeorge syndrome.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot:

 

  • Ventricular septal defect

  • Sub pulmonic stenosis

  • Overriding aorta

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Asymptomatic usually, rarely has severe cyanosis at birth, worsens as they get older.

  • Loud and harsh murmur at the upper sternal edge on day 1.

  • Do not usually develop heart failure.

 

ECG:

 

  • Normal at birth

  • RVH when older

 

Chest X-ray:

 

  • Usually, normal

  • Older children have upturned apex (boot shaped) + reduced vascular markings

 

Management:

 

  • 10% require BT shunt in newborn if severely cyanosed

  • Most have elective repair at 6–9 months.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Left-sided aortic arch is seen - This is typically seen in TOF where the aorta overrides the ventricular septal defect.

 

Option C. Subpulmonic stenosis determines the severity - The degree of obstruction in the right ventricular outflow tract, often due to subpulmonic stenosis, is a major determinant of the clinical presentation and severity in TOF.

 

Option D. Multiple ventricular septal defects may be seen - While a single, large VSD is a component of TOF, multiple VSDs are less common but may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tetralogy of Fallot can be associated with DiGeorge syndrome or Shprintzen velocardiofacial syndrome. The features of it include cardiac defects, abnormal facies, thymic hypoplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia. (CATCH 22)

 

Ref: O P Ghai 8th Edition, Page no. 417 to 420

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his failure to thrive and developmental delays. Karyotyping is performed, the result is shown below. What is the most common cardiac condition seen in this child?
 

 

What is the most common cardiac condition seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventricular Septal Defect

 

Option B:

 

Based on the image and clinical description provided, the karyotype shows an abnormal characteristic of Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. This is evidenced by the presence of three copies of chromosome 18. Children with Trisomy 18 often present with a range of clinical features, including developmental delays, failure to thrive, and distinctive craniofacial and hand features.

 

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common cardiac anomaly associated with Trisomy 18. VSD is a hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers of the heart, which allows oxygen-rich blood to mix with oxygen-poor blood, potentially causing heart failure and other complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial Septal Defect - While ASDs can occur in Trisomy 18, they are not as common as VSDs.

 

Option C. Mitral Valve Prolapse - This is not commonly associated with Trisomy 18.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis - This condition, characterized by the narrowing of the mitral valve, is also not commonly associated with Trisomy 18.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trisomy 18 (Edward Syndrome) - The 2nd most common autosomal trisomy.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Rocker bottom feet

  • Overlapping fingers

  • Clenched fist

  • Short sternum

  • Hypoplastic nails

  • Hypoplastic nasal alae

  • IUGR

  • Intellectual disability

  • Microcephaly

  • Hypertonia

  • Prominent occiput

  • Micrognathia

  • Limited hip abduction

  • Cleft lip / palate

 

Most common cardiac defects:

 

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

  • Atrial septal defect (ASD)

  • PDA

 

Most common cause of death: Central apnea

 

Prenatal screen lab findings:

 

  • Low alpha feto protein

  • Low unconjugated estriol

  • Low beta hCG

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter – 98, Page No. 3024

choices.text: Coarctation of Aorta
Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
Tetralogy of Fallot with Pulmonary atresia

questions.text: A mother presents to the pediatric emergency department with her 1-day-old newborn. The infant was referred from a primary healthcare center with a presumptive diagnosis of congenital heart disease. Upon physical examination, the pediatrician observes marked cyanosis. An echocardiogram is performed, which suggests a cyanotic heart condition that appears to be dependent on the patency of the ductus arteriosus for adequate systemic or pulmonary blood flow. Given the echocardiogram findings and clinical presentation, the pediatrician considers which congenital heart diseases could explain the cyanosis and which among them is not typically duct dependent. Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases is NOT typically duct dependent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Truncus arteriosus

 

Option A:

 

Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial vessel arising from the heart, supplying both systemic and pulmonary circulation. It does not typically depend on the ductus arteriosus for pulmonary blood flow because the common arterial trunk provides direct blood flow to the pulmonary arteries.

 

Ductal-dependent congenital heart disease encompasses severe cardiac malformations that rely on postnatal patency of the ductus arteriosus to maintain adequate circulation. Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) is most commonly used to maintain patency of the ductus arteriosus.


Explanation:

 

Option B. Coarctation of Aorta - Coarctation of the aorta is a condition of aortic narrowing, which can lead to obstruction of blood flow. After birth, as the ductus arteriosus closes, newborns can present with signs of heart failure or shock, making the condition duct dependent for systemic circulation.

 

Option C. Hypoplastic left heart syndrome - This is a critical condition where the left side of the heart is underdeveloped, and systemic blood flow is duct-dependent. Neonates with this condition depend on the patent ductus arteriosus for survival, as it allows the blood to bypass the underdeveloped left heart structures, providing systemic circulation.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot with Pulmonary atresia - In this condition, there is an obstruction (atresia) at the level of the pulmonary valve, which prevents blood from flowing from the right ventricle into the pulmonary arteries. The patent ductus arteriosus is essential for pulmonary blood flow in these patients, making this condition duct-dependent for pulmonary circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ductus dependent congenital heart diseases:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No. 2189 to 2191.

choices.text: Notching of 4th to 9th ribs can be seen
Can be associated with Turner's syndrome
Reverse 3 sign is noted on barium esophagography
Erosion of superior border of ribs is noted

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine visit. The mother reports no specific concerns but mentions that the child often complains of tiredness in the legs. On examination, the pediatrician notes a temperature discrepancy, with the child's legs being cooler than the hands. Pulse and blood pressure measurements reveal variability between the upper and lower extremities. Suspecting a cardiovascular issue, a chest X-ray was advised which reveals the following findings. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the condition suggested by the X-ray findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Erosion of superior border of ribs is noted

 

Option D:

 

The condition depicted in the X-ray is coarctation of the aorta. Rib notching, typically involving the inferior borders of the 4th to 9th ribs, is caused by collateral circulation that develops to bypass the coarctation. This increased flow through intercostal arteries causes the notching. The superior borders of the ribs are not typically involved in this process, which makes option D incorrect.

 

Coarctation of the aorta

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Very common diagnosis
  • Often diagnosed antenatally
  • Absent femoral pulses
  • Should be born in a cardiac center
  • If not detected antenatally, presents as sick infant with absent femoral pulses
  • No murmur, usually
  • Signs of right heart failure (large liver, low cardiac output)
  • May be breathless and severely acidotic
  • Associated with VSD and bicuspid aortic valve

 

ECG: Normal

 

Chest X-ray: Normal, or cardiomegaly with heart failure

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Notching of 4th to 9th ribs can be seen - This is a classic finding in coarctation of the aorta due to collateral circulation through intercostal arteries.

 

Option B. Can be associated with Turner's syndrome - Coarctation of the aorta is indeed associated with Turner's syndrome, which is a chromosomal disorder characterized by a 45, X0 karyotype.

 

Option C. Reverse 3 sign is noted on barium esophagography - The 'reverse 3' or '3' sign on barium swallow is characteristic of the indentation and post-stenotic dilation that occurs in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta, also called aortic narrowing, is a congenital condition whereby the aorta is narrow, usually in the area where the ductus arteriosus (ligamentum arteriosum after regression) inserts.

 

Management:

 

  • Resuscitate
  • Commence prostaglandin E1 or E2 (5-20 ng/kg per min)
  • Ventilate early (before transfer to cardiac center)
  • Surgery 24 hours later, usually through a left lateral thoracotomy, to resect the narrow segment, unless the whole aortic arch is small, in which case the surgery is performed via a median sternotomy on bypass.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, page 2753

choices.text: A2 B3 C4 D1
A3 B4 C2 D1
A3 B2 C4 D1
A3 B1 C4 D2

questions.text:
During a pediatric cardiology rotation, a medical resident is focusing on the mastery of heart sounds associated with various congenital heart conditions. To reinforce this knowledge, the attending physician asks the resident to match specific cardiac conditions with their typical auscultatory findings in children.

 

Match the cardiological conditions with their auscultatory findings:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A3 B1 C4 D2

 

Option D:

 

A3: Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) typically presents with a continuous "machinery" murmur throughout systole and diastole due to continuous flow of blood from the higher-pressure aorta to the lower-pressure pulmonary artery through the patent ductus arteriosus.

 

B1: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is characterized by a pan systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border due to the flow of blood from the higher-pressure left ventricle to the lower-pressure right ventricle.

 

C4: Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) classically presents with a silent, wide fixed split of S2 and may be associated with an ejection systolic murmur at the pulmonary area due to increased flow across the pulmonary valve.

 

D2: Tetralogy of Fallot can present with an ejection systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border due to right ventricular outflow tract obstruction; however, the murmur's quality and presence can vary depending on the severity of the obstruction and the presence of additional defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, page 9545

choices.text: Waterson’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta
Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta
Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery
Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of cyanotic heart disease is brought to the pediatric surgery outpatient department by their mother. The pediatric surgeon conducts a thorough examination and then engages in a teaching moment with the residents, discussing the various shunt surgeries available for managing such conditions. The surgeon presents several options and asks the residents to identify which statement about shunt surgeries is incorrect, emphasizing the need for precision in understanding and choosing the appropriate surgical intervention.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

 

Option D:

 

Pott’s shunt actually involves the anastomosis between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta, not the ascending aorta. This shunt is used to increase pulmonary blood flow in certain types of congenital heart defects. By connecting the left pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, blood flow to the lungs is increased, which can improve oxygenation in patients with cyanotic heart disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Waterson’s shunt: This is accurate as it describes connecting the right pulmonary artery to the ascending aorta, a method used to augment pulmonary blood flow in specific heart conditions.

 

Option B. Pott’s shunt: This correctly identifies the traditional Pott’s shunt connection between the left pulmonary artery and the descending aorta.

 

Option C. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: This accurately describes the connection between the subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery, a common procedure to increase pulmonary blood flow in cyanotic heart diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shunt surgeries are used in the palliative care in case of TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot). These surgeries include:

 

  1. Waterston’s shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

  2. Pott’s shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta

  3. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition page 9234

choices.text: Ostium primum ASD
VSD with severe pneumonia
Tetralogy of Fallot
Transposition of Great arteries

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric cardiology clinic by their mother due to repeated episodes of cyanosis, particularly bluish discoloration of the lips, which the mother notes are alleviated when the infant assumes a squatting position. During the physical examination, the pediatric cardiologist detects a holosystolic murmur. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing distinctive radiographic findings. Based on the X-ray provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tetralogy of Fallot

 

Option C:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most likely diagnosis given the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings.

 

TOF is a congenital heart defect characterized by four components: ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta.

 

The radiograph often shows a "boot-shaped" heart (coeur en sabot) due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and a concave pulmonary artery segment. The episodes of cyanosis, which improve with squatting (increasing systemic vascular resistance and decreasing the right-to-left shunt across the VSD), are characteristic of TOF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ostium primum ASD: This condition usually presents with signs of left-to-right shunt like a systolic murmur and evidence of pulmonary overcirculation on X-ray, not typically with cyanotic episodes or squatting.

 

Option B. VSD with severe pneumonia: While a large VSD could present with a holosystolic murmur, the chest X-ray in pneumonia would typically show consolidation or other signs of infection, rather than the structural changes seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Transposition of the Great Arteries: This condition is a cyanotic heart disease present from birth. The X-ray might show an "egg on a string" appearance due to the narrow mediastinum, but the clinical presentation is usually of consistent cyanosis that does not improve with squatting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is commonly asymptomatic at birth, with potential development of cyanosis and a distinctive murmur detectable early on. Initial ECGs are normal, evolving to show RVH in older children. Chest X-rays eventually reveal a "boot-shaped" heart and diminished vascular markings. Management typically involves elective surgical repair between 6-9 months, with severe cases requiring a BT shunt in the neonatal period.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 8th Edition, Page no. 417 to 420.

choices.text: Septum primum ASD
Septum secundum ASD
Septum atrium ASD
Mixed ASD

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to complaints of easy fatigability and failure to thrive. The child appears externally normal with no distinct physical anomalies. Upon auscultation, however, a wide splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is noted. An echocardiogram confirms the presence of an acyanotic congenital heart defect identified as an Atrial Septal Defect (ASD). Based on the clinical findings and the most common occurrence of ASD subtypes, you suspect the child has the most prevalent form of ASD. Which type of ASD is most commonly seen in the pediatric population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Septum secundum ASD

 

Option B:

 

The septum secundum ASD is the most common type of atrial septal defect, comprising 70-80% of all ASD cases. It occurs in the central part of the atrial septum and is often diagnosed later in childhood or even in adulthood due to less pronounced symptoms or being asymptomatic.

 

Secundum ASD is a defect in the center of the atrial septum involving the fossa ovalis.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Asymptomatic
  • Soft systolic murmur at upper left sternal edge
  • Fixed split S2 (difficult to hear)

 

ECG:

 

  • Partial right bundle-branch block (90%)
  • Right ventricle hypertrophy

 

Chest X-ray:

 

  • Increased pulmonary vascular markings

 

Management:

 

  • Closure at 3-5 years (ideally)
  • 90% undergo device closure in catheter laboratory
  • 10% undergo surgical closure (too large or personal preference)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Septum primum ASD: This type of ASD is less common and is located at the lower end of the atrial septum, near the atrioventricular valves. It is often associated with other congenital heart anomalies.

 

Option C. Septum atrium ASD: This is not a recognized subtype of ASD.

 

Option D. Mixed ASD: This refers to cases where there are multiple types of defects present in the septum, which is not a single distinct subtype and is less common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of Atrial septal defect (ASD):

 

  • Secundum ASD (MC; 80%)
  • Primum ASD (partial atrioventricular septal defect)
  • Sinus venosus ASD
  • Other

 

Ref: O P Ghai, Page No. 405-410.

choices.text: Ductus arteriosus undergoes physiological closure in 10-15 hours of birth
Fetus has 2 umbilical arteries and 1 umbilical vein
Ligamentum teres is formed from the Right umbilical vein
Foramen ovale closes to form Fossa ovalis

questions.text: As a new member of the pediatric department, you join a group of colleagues in the cafeteria who are discussing the nuances of fetal circulation. During the conversation, one of the colleagues poses a series of statements about fetal circulation for you to consider. Which of the following statements made by her is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ligamentum teres is formed from the Right umbilical vein

 

Option C:

 

The ligamentum teres, also known as the round ligament of the liver, is actually formed from the obliterated left umbilical vein, not the right. In fetal circulation, the right umbilical vein typically degenerates and is not present in the mature fetal circulatory system.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ductus arteriosus: This statement is true. The ductus arteriosus typically undergoes functional closure within the first 10-15 hours after birth due to increased oxygen levels and decreased levels of prostaglandins.

 

Option B. Umbilical vessels: This is a true statement. The fetus has two umbilical arteries that carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta and one umbilical vein that carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option D. Foramen ovale: This statement is true. The foramen ovale generally closes functionally soon after birth and anatomically over several months to become the fossa ovalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligamentum teres hepatis is formed from the Left Umbilical Vein and not the Right.

 

Mnemonic: Remember only LEFT (umbilical vein) is LEFT.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition.page 9258

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-day old child with complaints of bluish discoloration of skin. She has a referral letter with her from the primary health center mentioning the condition as cyanotic heart disease. The X-ray re3veals the following findings. What is the diagnosis based on clinical history and X-ray findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Transposition of Great Arteries

 

Option A:

 

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) is a congenital heart defect where the two main arteries leaving the heart are reversed. It is characterized by cyanosis that is often noticeable shortly after birth, as the blood flow is not properly oxygenated. The chest X-ray of a patient with TGA may not have the classic "boot-shaped" heart seen in Tetralogy of Fallot, but it might show an egg-on-a-string appearance due to the abnormal position of the transposed great arteries.

 

Remember - The clinical history of cyanotic heart disease and the X-ray findings of egg on the string/egg on side appearance is seen in case Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Trilogy of Fallot: This is an incorrect as egg on string appearance is not seen in trilogy of fallot.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot: While Tetralogy of Fallot does present with cyanosis, the X-ray typically shows a "boot-shaped" heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy, which may not be present in a newborn.

 

Option D. Atrial Septal Defect: ASD typically does not present with cyanosis in the neonatal period and is generally considered an acyanotic heart defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transposition of the great arteries causes severe cyanosis due to improper connections of the major heart arteries, leading to mixed blood circulation. Infants typically present with cyanosis and are at high risk if not diagnosed early. The ECG may be normal, and the chest X-ray can sometimes show increased pulmonary markings. Urgent management includes resuscitation, balloon atrial septostomy if needed, and an early arterial switch operation.

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 540-543.

choices.text: Supravalvular pulmonary stenosis
Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Supravalvular Tricuspid stenosis
Supravalvular Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her mother, who reports her daughter has been experiencing constipation, muscle soreness, and weakness. The mother also expresses concern about the child's poor academic performance. Upon evaluation, the child displays a very sociable demeanor, a broad forehead, and distinctive facial features. Laboratory tests reveal normal complete blood count (CBC) results but an elevated serum calcium level. Based on these findings, the child is diagnosed with Williams syndrome. Considering the diagnosis of Williams syndrome, which cardiac abnormality is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Supravalvular aortic stenosis

 

Option B:

 

Williams syndrome is often associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, the most common being supravalvular aortic stenosis (SVAS). SVAS is a congenital narrowing of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve, and can lead to a variety of cardiac symptoms and complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supravalvular pulmonary stenosis: While pulmonary artery stenosis can occur in Williams syndrome, it is less common than supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

Option C. Supravalvular tricuspid stenosis: This is not a typical feature of Williams syndrome.

 

Option D. Supravalvular mitral stenosis: Mitral stenosis is not characteristically associated with Williams syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

William syndrome (deletion of chromosome 7q11.23)

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Round face with full cheeks are lips
  • Intellectual disability
  • Friendly personality
  • Broad forehead

 

Associated features:

 

Hypercalcemia > 11mg/dL (leads to constipation, muscle weakness, lethargy, depression etc.)

 

CVS: supravalvular aortic stenosis

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No. 4242.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that her son has been experiencing fever, joint pain, and a rash. Upon examination, the healthcare provider notes tender, swollen joints, particularly in the knees and ankles, and observes a faint erythematous rash on the trunk and extremities. The child also has a recent history of a sore throat. Based on these findings, rheumatic fever is considered as a potential diagnosis. Among the listed options, which is not considered a major criterion for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elevated ESR

 

Option D:

 

Elevated ESR (Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate) is not one of the major criteria for diagnosing rheumatic fever. It is often used as a supportive or ancillary test to indicate inflammation but does not alone constitute a major criterion in the diagnosis of rheumatic fever.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythema marginatum: This is one of the major criteria for rheumatic fever, characterized by a distinctive rash that often appears on the trunk and limbs.

 

Option B. Carditis: Carditis, or inflammation of the heart, is a major criterion for rheumatic fever and can affect the myocardium, endocardium, and pericardium.

 

Option C. Chorea: Sydenham's chorea, characterized by rapid, involuntary movements, is another major criterion for diagnosing rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rheumatic fever: Diagnosed by modified Duckett–Jones criteria (two major or one major + two minor criteria)

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Chapter -16, Pg. 432.

choices.text: Complete atrioventricular septal defect
Critical pulmonary stenosis
Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

questions.text: During your first week in the pediatrics department, a senior tasks you with reviewing the ECG of a newborn in the NICU. Initially healthy at birth, the infant quickly became unwell and developed cyanosis, with no detectable heart murmur. The ECG displays a superior axis, absence of right ventricular voltages, and pronounced P waves. Based on these ECG findings, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tricuspid atresia

 

Option A:

 

Tricuspid atresia is characterized by the absence of a tricuspid valve, leading to an underdeveloped or absent right ventricle. The ECG findings of a superior axis, absent right ventricular voltages, and large P waves are indicative of tricuspid atresia, as these findings reflect the lack of right ventricular activity and the resulting atrial enlargement.

 

ECG findings typically include a superior axis, absence of right ventricular voltages, and enlarged P waves.

 

Chest X-ray findings can vary, showing either decreased or increased pulmonary vascular markings.

 

Management strategies include the surgical insertion of a BT shunt for severe cyanosis, PA banding for heart failure, a Hemi-Fontan procedure after 6 months, and ultimately, a Fontan procedure between the ages of 3 to 5 years.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Complete atrioventricular septal defect: This condition often presents with a more complex ECG pattern and typically includes heart murmurs due to the defect in the septum and abnormal valve formation.

 

Option C. Critical pulmonary stenosis: This would more likely show signs of right ventricular hypertrophy on ECG if the right ventricle is pressure-loaded, which is not indicated by the absence of right ventricular voltages.

 

Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection: This condition might show signs of right heart overload on ECG, but the specific findings of superior axis and absent right ventricular voltages are more characteristic of tricuspid atresia.

 

Educational Objective:


Tricuspid atresia leads to a significantly underdeveloped right ventricle. Clinically, affected individuals may present with cyanosis following ductal closure in duct-dependent circulations, often without a heart murmur, and can appear healthy at birth.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No. 2118; OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 420-423.

questions.text: A 28-week-old preterm girl, weighing 1100 grams, is being cared for in the NICU. After an initially stable period, she starts showing signs of respiratory distress characterized by tachypnea and mild subcostal retractions on day 6, along with widened pulse pressure. There is no cyanosis, but a continuous murmur is noted along the left sternal border during auscultation. The chest X-ray reveals pulmonary congestion. To alleviate her symptoms, which of the following medications should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Indomethacin

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, widened pulse pressure, a continuous murmur, and pulmonary congestion in a preterm infant, suggests a diagnosis of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

 

Indomethacin, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is often used to encourage the closure of the PDA in preterm infants by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, which is responsible for keeping the ductus arteriosus open.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: While dexamethasone is used in the management of bronchopulmonary dysplasia and to reduce inflammation, it is not the first choice for managing PDA.

 

Option B. Racemic Epinephrine: Typically used for its bronchodilator effects in conditions like croup, not for managing PDA.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Used in heart failure and certain arrhythmias but not the primary treatment for PDA in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) involves the persistence of the ductus arteriosus beyond the neonatal period. Most cases are asymptomatic, but a continuous murmur can often be heard in the left infraclavicular area. ECGs are typically normal, though large PDAs may show signs of left ventricular loading. Chest X-rays are usually normal, with large PDAs showing increased pulmonary vascular markings. Management includes catheter-based closure with a coil or device at around 1 year of age, or surgical ligation between 1–3 months for significant cases.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 404-405.

questions.text:
A medical student is rotating in the neonatal intensive care unit and is being quizzed on the identification and purpose of various neonatal care devices. The attending physician shows the student four images labeled A, B, C, and D, each depicting a different device. The student is asked to match the following devices with their corresponding names:

 

 

  1. Radiant Warmer
  2. Phototherapy unit
  3. Bilirubinometer
  4. Incubator
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A2 B1 C4 D3

 

Option C: 

 

 

Explanation:

 

A2 - Phototherapy Unit: Image A shows a neonate under a blue light, characteristic of a phototherapy unit used for treating hyperbilirubinemia in newborns by converting bilirubin into more soluble forms through structural isomerization.

 

B1 - Radiant Warmer: Image B depicts a device used to maintain the body temperature of neonates by providing radiant heat. This is important for premature infants or those who cannot regulate their temperature.

 

C4 - Incubator: Image C illustrates an enclosed apparatus designed to provide a controlled and protective environment for premature or ill newborns, which is indicative of an incubator.

 

D3 - Bilirubinometer: Image D shows a handheld device being used on a neonate's forehead, which is typically a non-invasive bilirubinometer used to measure bilirubin levels in newborns.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 2190

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is reviewing neonatal reflexes with a medical student. They observe four different infants demonstrating various reflexes as shown in images labeled A, B, C, and D. The resident asks the student to match the reflexes to the images shown. Which of the following is the correct match of the neonatal reflexes to their corresponding images?

 

 

  1. Asymmetrical tonic neck reflex
  2. Palmar Grasp Reflex
  3. Parachute reflex
  4. Moro’s Reflex
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A4 B3 C1 D2

 

Option D:

 

 

Explanation:

 

A4 - Moro’s Reflex: Image A displays an infant with arms outstretched and crying, which is characteristic of the Moro reflex. This startle reflex is typically elicited by a sudden loss of support, causing the infant to react with arms flinging outwards and then curling in.

 

B3 - Parachute Reflex: Image B shows an infant being held horizontally face down, appearing to extend the arms outward as if to break a fall, indicative of the parachute reflex. This reflex develops later, usually around 6 to 7 months of age, and is not present at birth.

 

C1 - Asymmetrical Tonic Neck Reflex: Image C illustrates an infant lying with head turned to one side, the arm and leg on the face side are extended (fencer's position), and the opposite arm and leg are flexed, which is indicative of the asymmetrical tonic neck reflex.

 

D2 - Palmar Grasp Reflex: Image D shows an infant grasping an adult's finger, demonstrating the palmar grasp reflex. This reflex is present at birth and fades around 5 to 6 months of age.

 

Educational objective:

 

Neonatal Reflexes

 

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No-141.

questions.text: A neonatal resuscitation team is attending to a 30-week preterm infant in the delivery room who requires resuscitation, including intravenous access for medication and fluid administration. Given the gestational age and the delicate nature of the infant, which size IV cannula is appropriate for use in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24 G

 

Option D:

 

The appropriate size of IV cannula for a preterm infant depends on their weight and gestational age. The most commonly used sizes are 24 G and 26 G for infants less than 1000 grams, and 22 G for infants weighing more than 1000 grams.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 18 G is too large and not appropriate for a preterm infant, as it may cause damage to the veins.

 

Option B: 22 G is appropriate for preterm infants weighing more than 1000 grams, but may be too large for infants less than 1000 grams.

 

Option C: 14 G is too large and not appropriate for a preterm infant, as it may cause damage to the veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

24 G and 26 G for infants less than 1000 grams, and 22 G for infants weighing more than 1000 grams.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 2600

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman delivers a male infant at 38 weeks of gestation. The delivery process proceeds without complications, but the newborn appears lethargic immediately after birth and presents with bradycardia. Initial resuscitative efforts include oxygenation via bag and mask followed by endotracheal intubation. Despite these interventions, the infant's heart rate remains at 40 beats per minute. Based on the current clinical status, what is the most appropriate subsequent step in the management of this neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Begin chest compressions

 

Option A:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, if the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation and oxygenation, the next step is to initiate chest compressions. Chest compressions, combined with effective ventilation, are critical in providing circulatory support to improve heart rate and systemic perfusion in severely bradycardic or asystolic neonates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Administer IV atropine: An anticholinergic medication used to treat bradycardia in adults and older children, primarily when it's thought to be due to vagal stimulation. In neonates, the most common cause of bradycardia is hypoxia, and the primary treatment is effective ventilation, not atropine.

 

Option C. Administer IV epinephrine: Epinephrine is used in neonatal resuscitation if the heart rate remains very low (below 60 bpm) despite 60 seconds of effective chest compressions combined with adequate ventilation. It is not the first step in management but is considered if initial resuscitative efforts (ventilation and chest compressions) fail to increase the heart rate.

 

Option D. Administer IV calcium chloride: Used in specific situations such as hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, and calcium channel blocker overdose. It is not typically used in standard neonatal resuscitation, especially not as an initial step.

 

The first actions in neonatal resuscitation are ensuring effective ventilation and, if necessary, chest compressions. Calcium chloride would only be considered under very specific circumstances and usually after other more common causes of neonatal distress have been addressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In neonatal resuscitation, If the HR is less than 60 bpm despite PPV with 100% oxygen, then chest compressions are given for 60 seconds.

 

If the HR is still less than 60 bpm, then drug therapy (usually epinephrine) is indicated.

 

Neonatal Resuscitation Algorithm-2015 update

 

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Positive pressure ventilation
Umbilical vein catheterization

questions.text: A newborn infant, delivered at 38 weeks of gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery, is observed to have inadequate respiratory effort and a heart rate below 100 beats per minute immediately post-delivery. The infant is also noted to be cyanotic and not breathing effectively. Upon being alerted, the neonatal resuscitation team arrives quickly at the scene. Considering the urgent need for neonatal resuscitation, what is the most appropriate initial intervention to undertake for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Positive pressure ventilation

 

Option A: 

 

Positive pressure ventilation is the most appropriate initial step for neonatal resuscitation in cases where the newborn has poor respiratory effort, as in the clinical case presented. Positive pressure ventilation can help to open up the infant's airway, improve oxygenation, and increase the heart rate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chest compressions are indicated in cases where the newborn has a heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation. This is not the most appropriate initial step in the clinical case presented, as the heart rate is between 60-100 beats per minute.

 

Option C. Epinephrine administration is indicated in cases where the newborn has a heart rate of less than 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation and chest compressions. This is not the most appropriate initial step in the clinical case presented, as the heart rate is between 60-100 beats per minute.

 

Option D: Umbilical vein catheterization is not an initial step in neonatal resuscitation. It may be indicated later in the resuscitation process if intravenous access is needed for medications or fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal Resuscitation Algorithm-2015 update

 

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 130.

questions.text: In the neonatal intensive care unit, a premature newborn presenting with respiratory distress requires immediate resuscitation. The infant's weight is recorded at 1,500 grams. Given the critical need for precise and controlled ventilation in such a delicate patient, selecting the correct size of the Ambu bag (manual resuscitator) is essential. Which of the following Ambu bag sizes is most appropriate for the resuscitation of this premature infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 mL.

 

Option B: 250 mL.

 

Neonatal resuscitation requires proper equipment, including an Ambu bag, to deliver positive pressure ventilation to the newborn. The size of the Ambu bag is important, as it can affect the amount of tidal volume delivered to the infant.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: A 150 mL Ambu bag is too small for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams. This size would not deliver enough tidal volume to effectively ventilate the infant.

 

Option C and D: A 500 mL and 750 ml Ambu bag may be too large for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams. This size may deliver too much tidal volume, which can be harmful to the infant.

 

Educational objective:

 

The importance of selecting the appropriate equipment size in neonatal resuscitation to ensure effective and safe ventilation. Using a 250 mL Ambu bag for a premature infant weighing 1,500 grams is appropriate to provide the necessary respiratory support without causing injury to the infant's delicate respiratory structures.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Suction the mouth & nose and start bag & mask ventilation

questions.text: A newborn girl is delivered via emergency cesarean section to a 34-year-old mother whose pregnancy was marked by hypertension and concerning fetal heart rate patterns noted during prenatal monitoring. At birth, the baby is observed to be coated in thick green meconium. Upon a thorough examination, the infant is found to be apneic, bradycardic, and displaying poor muscle tone. As the pediatrician on duty, you are tasked with initiating resuscitation. What is the first step you should take in the resuscitation process for this neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suction the mouth & nose and start bag & mask ventilation.

 

Option B:

 

Ventilation is initiated after meconium is removed. The goal is to remove airway meconium and to prevent its aspiration into the small airways where ventilation-perfusion mismatch may occur with deleterious effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IV bicarbonate cannot be used in this case, As the initial management is to maintain the airway.

 

Option C: Bag-and-mask ventilation can be initiated once the airway is cleared.

 

Option D: Chest compressions is indicated if the HR is less than 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clearing the airway of meconium through suctioning before initiating positive pressure ventilation is crucial in non-vigorous meconium stained baby to prevent meconium aspiration syndrome.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: The most common type is Type C
The child may present with drooling of saliva
Type E is associated with only atresia
On Xray coiling of NG tube can be seen

questions.text: A full-term newborn baby is brought to the hospital by the mother with concerns that the baby starts coughing during feeding, leading to inadequate feeding for the past 2 days. The examination reveals signs of dehydration. Intravenous fluids (IVF) are initiated, and an X-ray is performed, revealing the anomaly shown in the image. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray findings, which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Type E is associated with only atresia

 

Option C:

 

The baby is presenting with drooling of saliva because of the atresia and coughing during breast feeding and the X-ray image provided shows a nasogastric tube coiling back on itself, suggestive of an esophageal atresia, where the esophagus does not form properly and is not connected to the stomach.

 

 

However, Type E, also known as isolated esophageal atresia without a fistula, is very rare and is not characterized by the presence of a fistula,

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The most common type is Type C: This is true. Type C esophageal atresia with a distal tracheoesophageal fistula is the most common type, accounting for about 86% of cases.

 

Option B. The child may present with drooling of saliva: This is a common finding in esophageal atresia due to the inability to swallow saliva.

 

Option D. On X-ray, coiling of the NG tube can be seen: The provided X-ray image demonstrates this finding, which is characteristic of esophageal atresia when the NG tube cannot pass into the stomach and coils in the blind-ending esophageal pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TEF

 

 Clinical manifestation

 

  • Excessive salivation.
  • Coughing, choking, cyanosis,
  • Apnea
  • Abdominal distention.

 

Diagnosis - Coiling of NG tube can be seen in X-ray, along with Gas presence in stomach.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st  Edition – Page No- 7661-7667.

choices.text: The most common type of it is bochdalek hernia.
Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
It’s a Posterolateral defect.
All of the above.

questions.text: A mother bring her new born baby with complaints of some breathing difficulties. On examination the baby had a difficulty in breathing along with scooped abdomen. On further investigations, an X ray revealed the presence of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and is given below. Which of the following is true regarding the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

Option D:

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is the Bochdalek hernia, which indeed results from a failure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane to close properly during fetal development. This leads to a posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, which allows abdominal contents to herniate into the thoracic cavity, often leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and subsequent respiratory distress after birth. The X-ray provided is consistent with such a diagnosis, showing abdominal contents in the chest cavity, which is indicative of a diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Pathophysiology and cause of CDH

 

  • Cause is unknown
  • Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing embryo Abdominal contents herniate and compress the ipsilateral developing lung, causing pulmonary hypoplasia and hypertension.

 

Clinical Presentation

 

  • Mild to severe respiratory distress
  • Tachypnea, cyanosis, dyspnea 
  • Absent breath sound.
  • Shock.

 

Three general presentations –

 

  • Severe respiratory distress - at the time of birth (Severe hypoplasia)
  • Respiratory deterioration hours after delivery (honeymoon period).
  • Benefit from correction of hypoxemia and pulmonary hypertension.

 

Diagnosis; Therapeutic Symptoms Radiographic study (Prenatally as early as 25 week of gestation)

 

Therapeutic

 

  • Supportive treatment of respiratory distress (Use of endotracheal intubation, oxygenation).
  • Prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Surgical reduction of hernia and repair of defect.

 

Surgical Care- Antenatal

 

Open fetal surgery: Open fetal surgery: remove the compression of the abdominal viscera. High risk for fetus and the mother. No survival advantage.

 

Fetal tracheal occlusion: Fetal tracheal occlusion: stimulation of lung growth with accumulation of fluid. Result in larger but persistent abnormal lung.

 

Steroids therapy weekly to improve lung function is controversial (risk of brain and body development

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia is correct, as it is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Option B. Failure of normal closure of the pleuroperitoneal membrane is also correct. This process usually completes between the seventh and tenth week of gestation, and failure leads to CDH.

 

Option C. The description of a posterolateral defect is accurate for a Bochdalek hernia, which typically occurs on the left side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Diaphragmatic hernia – The most common type of it is Bochdalek hernia. It is due to the pleuroperitoneal membrane defect in the Posterolateral aspect, Whereas Morgagni hernia is due to the Anterior pleuroperitoneal membrane defect.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st  Edition – Page No- 3855-3856

choices.text: Ask the child to vomit by inserting finger.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to sudden onset of breathing difficulty. The mother reports that while playing, her son accidentally swallowed a coin. Upon examination, the child is found to be gasping for air. An X-ray is performed, revealing the following finding. Based on the X-ray findings and the child's clinical presentation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Immediate removal of foreign body

 

Option A:

 

The X-ray shows a coin lodged in the airway, which is a life-threatening emergency due to the risk of complete airway obstruction. The child's symptoms of gasping indicate significant respiratory distress, necessitating prompt intervention. Immediate removal of the foreign body is required to restore airway patency and prevent further complications such as hypoxia and potential respiratory arrest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Instead of CT Chest, the most appropriate next step will be immediate removal of the foreign body.

 

Option C. Wait and Watch is done in case of FB in esophagus.

 

Option D. Ask the child to vomit by inserting a finger: This is contraindicated as it can potentially push the foreign body further into the airway and worsen the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a foreign body in the respiratory tree - the best management is Immediate removal of the foreign body.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition – Page No- 8743.

questions.text: A 25-year-old mother named Mala delivered her first child at a primary health care center. The delivery was noted to be complicated, with the neonate having a delayed cry and subsequent development of neurological signs. The medical officer observed signs consistent with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) and promptly referred the newborn to a higher-level facility for further evaluation and management. Upon examination at the referral center, the neonate exhibited hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflexes, recurrent focal seizures, and miotic pupils. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely stage of HIE according to the Sarnat and Sarnat staging system?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2

 

Option B: 

 

Based on the clinical findings of hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflex and recurrent focal seizures, which are typically seen in case of Stage 2 of HIE.

 

HIE - Refers to CNS dysfunction or encephalopathy associated with Perinatal asphyxia.

Potential to cause mortality and long term sequelae like disabilities and cerebral palsy.

 

Etiology: Pathologically, any factors which interfere with the circulation between maternal and fetal blood exchange.

 

Pathophysiology of Asphyxia

 

Redistribution of blood flow to vital organs (brain, heart and adrenal) to prevent hypoxic damage. ‘Diving Reflex’

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Stage 1 (Mild HIE): This stage is characterized by hyperalertness, jitteriness, increased muscle tone, irritable and exaggerated reflexes, without significant alterations in level of consciousness or seizures.

 

Option C: Stage 3 (Severe HIE): Neonates in this stage present with stupor or coma, flaccid muscle tone, absent reflexes, and often have severe autonomic dysfunction.

 

Option D: Stage 4 is not classed under Sarnat and Sarnat staging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 12509

choices.text: Status maromaratus with basal ganglia infarcts

questions.text:
A concerned mother was referred from district hospital to medical college with her 1-day-old neonate, who was born at home following an uncomplicated pregnancy. She reports that the neonate had a delayed cry immediately post-birth and has been feeding poorly since. Additionally, she noticed a few episodes of what she describes as "seizure-like" movements. Given these concerns, a MRI of the neonate's brain was advised. The MRI shows the following abnormality.

 

 

Based on the clinical history and MRI findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periventricular leukomalacia

 

Option A: Periventricular leukomalacia

 

This MRI shows increased periventricular T2 signal on FLAIR image indicating Periventricular leukomalacia.

 

Periventricular Leukomalacia (PVL) PVL has emerged as the principal form of brain injury in premature infants.

 

  1. Death of white matter (WM) in the brain’s Periventricular (PV) region

  2. Caused by decrease in O2 or blood flow to PV WM

 

Clinical Correlates –

 

  • Developmental delay

  • Seizures

  • Spastic diplegia

 

Diagnosis and Management Postnatal Treatment

 

  • Postnatal resuscitation (NICU)

  • Minimize the risk for fluctuation CBF & BP – avoid unnecessary BP, suctioning, rapid infusions, pneumothorax – avoid ventilator asynchrony.

  • Correct coagulation disturbances

  • Indomethacin

  • Antioxidants (SOD)

  • Management of posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Germinal matrix hemorrhage: This condition involves bleeding into the germinal matrix, a highly vascularized area of the brain in preterm infants. It is more common in very premature neonates and would typically show blood in the subependymal region on MRI, not diffuse periventricular white matter changes.

 

Option C: Status marmoratus with basal ganglia infarcts: Status marmoratus is a condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the basal ganglia due to excessive myelination following injury. It is associated with basal ganglia infarcts and would primarily affect the deep structures of the brain rather than the periventricular white matter.

 

Option D. Periventricular inflammation with ventriculitis: This would involve inflammation and infection around the ventricles and within the ventricles themselves. MRI would likely show evidence of inflammation, such as ventricular enlargement and ependymal enhancement, rather than the diffuse white matter changes seen in PVL.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common neuropathologic finding in children with spastic diplegia is periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), which is visualized on MRI in more than 70% of cases. MRI typically shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter (due to reduced oxygen or blood flow) with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles. The potential clinical outcomes of PVL include developmental delays, seizures, and spastic diplegia.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 12347

choices.text: Recommend cessation of breast-feeding for 48 hours and supplement with formula.
Wait 6 hours and retest the serum bilirubin level.

questions.text: A mother brought her 30-hour-old newborn to the pediatric clinic due to the development of jaundice, which is noticeable on the infant's face and chest. The infant is breastfeeding well and appears healthy on examination. Laboratory tests reveal a total bilirubin level of 17 mg/dL. Considering the infant's age, clinical presentation, and bilirubin level, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start phototherapy.

 

Option B:

Although the etiology of hyperbilirubinemia must be investigated, phototherapy should be started based on the increased levels of bilirubin.

 

For full-term infants without hemolysis, phototherapy is initiated at the following bilirubin levels: 16-18 mg/dL at an age of 24 to 48 hours.

 

18-20 mg/dL at 49 to 72 hours; and

 

more than or equal to 20 mg/dL at 72 hours or more.

 

Phototherapy is often used to treat unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with the unclothed infant placed under a bank of lights, the eyes shielded, and hydration maintained. The blue-green light of wavelength 460-490 nm changes the skin’s bilirubin into a water-soluble polar compound called Lumirubin which can be excreted from the body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cessation of breastfeeding: This is not recommended as a first-line intervention for jaundice. Breastfeeding should be encouraged to promote hydration and bowel movements, which can help reduce bilirubin levels.

 

Option C. Wait and retest: Given the high bilirubin level for the infant's age, waiting without intervention could put the infant at risk for developing bilirubin encephalopathy. Immediate intervention is warranted.

 

Option D. Exchange transfusion: This is reserved for critically high bilirubin levels or when bilirubin levels do not respond to intensive phototherapy, especially if signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy are present. Given the current bilirubin level and the age of the infant, phototherapy is the most appropriate initial step.

 

Educational objective:

 

Physiological jaundice represents physiological immaturity of the neonates to handle increased bilirubin production.  Visible jaundice usually appears between 24-72 hr of age. Total serum bilirubin (TSB) level usually peaks by 3 days of age and then falls in term neonates. TSB levels are below the designated cut-offs for phototherapy. It does not require any treatment.

 

Pathological jaundice - TSB levels have been arbitrarily defined as pathological if it exceeds 5 mg/ dl on first day, 10 mg/dl on second day, or 15 mg/ dl thereafter in term babies. Such jaundice warrants investigation for the cause and therapeutic intervention such as phototherapy. Appearance of jaundice within 24 hr, TSB levels above the expected normal range, presence of clinical jaundice beyond 3 weeks and conjugated bilirubin (dark urine staining the nappy) would be categorized under this category.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 172-175.

questions.text: A very preterm infant, 6 days old and on enteral feeding, presents with acute symptoms including crying with leg flexion, severe abdominal distension with visible bowel loops, temperature instability, and lethargy. An abdominal X-ray reveals the presence of portal venous gas, a critical finding in this clinical context. Based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings, which stage of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is this very preterm infant most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NEC Stage 2B

 

Option C: NEC Stage 2B

 

Portal venous gas is seen in NEC Stage 2B.

 

Necrotizing Enterocolitis probably results from an interaction between loss of mucosal integrity due to factors like ischemia, infection, inflammation, and the host's response to that injury like circulatory, immunologic, inflammatory responses resulting in necrosis of the affected area.

 

NEC is an acquired neonatal acute intestinal necrosis of unknown etiology. NEC is the most common life-threatening emergency of the gastrointestinal tract in the newborn.  Various degrees of mucosal or transmural necrosis of the intestine occurs.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Fulminant presentation
  • Slow, paroxysmal presentation
  • The onset of NEC usually occurs in the 1st 2 weeks of life (with a mean age at onset of 12 days) but can be as late as 3 months of age in VLBW infants
  • Abdominal (enteric) signs: Distension, Tenderness, Gastric aspirate, vomiting Ileus Abdominal wall erythema, induration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: NEC Stage 1 (Suspected NEC) is characterized by nonspecific and mild systemic and gastrointestinal symptoms, such as temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, and mild abdominal distension, without the more severe radiographic findings.

 

Option B: NEC Stage 2A (Definite NEC, mildly ill) involves more evident gastrointestinal symptoms, including absent bowel sounds and mild abdominal tenderness, but lacks the severe systemic signs and advanced radiographic findings seen in Stage 2B.

 

Option D: NEC Stage 3A (Advanced NEC, severely ill without shock) includes severe systemic illness with features like severe apnea, bradycardia, and the presence of advanced radiographic findings, but not yet in shock, which would indicate Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Nelson pediatrics 2018 Edition, Page No-685; Ghai 8th Edition pg 165

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-day-old baby, initially weighing 2.5 kg at birth, for a follow-up visit. The baby appears alert and active but presents with noticeable jaundice. The baby's weight has decreased to 2 kg, and the stool color is described as yellow. Considering the baby's age, weight loss, and clinical presentation, what is the most likely cause of the jaundice observed in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breastfeeding jaundice

 

Option C: 

Breastfeeding jaundice typically occurs within the first week of life and can be associated with inadequate breast milk intake, leading to dehydration and increased bilirubin levels due to reduced stool production and, consequently, less bilirubin excretion. The significant weight loss (from 2.5 kg to 2 kg) suggests inadequate feeding, which supports the diagnosis of breastfeeding jaundice. The baby being alert and active with yellow stools also aligns with this condition, as cholestasis typically presents with acholic (pale) stools and possibly more significant systemic symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Physiological jaundice usually appears on the 2nd or 3rd day of life, peaking around the 4th to 5th day, but it would not typically cause significant weight loss or be the sole reason for concern in an otherwise healthy infant.
 

Option B: Breast milk jaundice tends to appear later than breastfeeding jaundice, usually at the end of the first week into the second week of life and is associated with lipoprotein lipase enzyme in the mother's breast milk that can increase bilirubin levels. It wouldn't be the leading cause of jaundice in a 5-day-old infant, especially with significant weight loss.
 

Option D: Cholestatic jaundice, which results from impaired bile flow, would not typically present this early without other signs of liver dysfunction and would be associated with pale or acholic stools due to the lack of bile excretion. (increased conjugated bilirubin)

 

Educational Objective

 

Exclusively breastfed infants have a different pattern of physiological jaundice as compared to artificially fed babies.

 

  • Jaundice in breastfed babies usually appears between 24-72 hr of age, peaks by 5-15 days of life and disappears by the third week of life.

  • One-third of all breastfed babies are detected to have mild clinical jaundice in the third week of life, which may persist into the 2nd to 3rd month of life in a few babies. This increased frequency of jaundice in breastfed babies is not related to characteristics of breast milk but rather to inadequate breastfeeding (breastfeeding jaundice).

  • Ensuring optimum breastfeeding would help decrease this kind of jaundice.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 8th Edition Page No- 172

questions.text: An eight-day-old male infant is brought to the emergency department in a state of dehydration and shock. Physical examination reveals generalized hyperpigmentation but normal external genitalia. Laboratory tests show hypoglycemia, hyponatremia with a sodium level of 123 mEq/L, and hyperkalemia with a potassium level of 7 mEq/L. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

 

Option A: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

 

The clinical features mentioned in this child with the features of hyperpigmentation, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia is suggestive of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired cortisol synthesis. It results from the deficiency of one of the five enzymes required for the synthesis of cortisol in the adrenal cortex. In this case, 21-hydroxylase enzyme is deficient, which is required for the production of Aldosterone. Decreased aldosterone leads to hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. On the other hand, the substrates are bypassed to produce more sex hormones, which can lead to virilization in females and precocious puberty in males.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acute gastroenteritis with dehydration: While this can cause dehydration and shock, it would not typically result in the combination of symptoms observed.

 

Option C: Adrenal hemorrhage and shock: Adrenal hemorrhage could cause acute adrenal insufficiency, leading to shock, but it is less likely to present with the mentioned symptoms.

 

Option D: Hyperaldosteronism: This condition would lead to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, which is the opposite of what is observed in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)

 

  • A group of autosomal recessive defects in steroid synthesis, is characterized by deficiency of adrenocortical hormones on one hand and excess of steroid precursors on the other.
  • CAH is the commonest adrenal disorder in childhood.
  • 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the commonest form of CAH accounting for over 90% of all cases. This disorder is associated with diminished synthesis of the cortisol and aldosterone.
  • Classic presentation of dehydration, shock, electrolyte imbalances, and hyperpigmentation in a neonate.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 11618

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is present to the emergency department in shock, displaying signs of circulatory collapse. Despite immediate resuscitation efforts, the emergency team is unable to establish intravenous access. Considering the critical condition and the urgent need for vascular access to deliver fluids and medications, what is the next best step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation

 

Option A: 

 

Intraosseous cannulation is straightforward and safe in children less than 6 years.

 

Intraosseous infusion (IO) is the process of injecting medications, fluids, or blood products directly into the marrow of a bone. The intraosseous infusion technique is used to provide fluids and medication when intravenous access is not available or not feasible. Intraosseous infusions allow for the administered medications and fluids to go directly into the vascular system. It is an alternative to the preferred intravascular route when the latter cannot be established in a timely manner in emergent situations. The most common site of insertion is the antero-medial aspect of the upper, proximal tibia as this site lies just under the skin and is easily located.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Intracardiac infusion: This is a rarely used, high-risk procedure that is considered only when other methods of access are not available or have failed, and the patient is in extremis. It carries significant risks and is not the first alternative when intravenous access cannot be obtained.

 

Option C. Thoracotomy: This is a surgical procedure that is not indicated for the purpose of vascular access and is not appropriate in the context of shock without evidence of conditions such as a traumatic cardiac arrest requiring open cardiac massage.

 

Option D. Intra-arterial access: While possible, intra-arterial access is not typically used for resuscitation purposes and is more complex to achieve than intraosseous access. It is not the preferred method in an emergency, especially in pediatric patients.

 

Educational objective:

 

Intraosseous cannulation is the recommended method for gaining rapid vascular access when intravenous attempts fail, especially in an emergency setting involving pediatric patients. The proximal tibia is the most common site for insertion. This method is relatively safe, fast, and effective for resuscitation in critical situations.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st Edition page 9232

questions.text:
A pediatrician evaluates the primitive reflexes of a newborn during a routine checkup. The physician is specifically assessing the Moro reflex. Which sequence correctly identifies the stages of the Moro reflex in the order they occur?

 

  1. Extension and abduction of upper limbs
  2. Anterior flexion of upper limb
  3. Opening of hands
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3→ 1 → 2

 

Option C: 

 

Explanation:

 

The Moro reflex, also known as the startle reflex, is a primitive reflex seen in newborns. The correct sequence of the Moro reflex:

 

Opening of hands (28 weeks) and Extension & Abduction of upper limbs (32 weeks) and followed by Adduction of upper limbs 37 weeks.

 

This reflex is typically present at birth and fades around 4 to 6 months of age.

 

Note - The most common cause of depressed or absent Moro reflex is a HIE stage3 (hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy), Down syndrome & kernicterus. An asymmetrical Moro reflex is indicative of brachial plexus injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential appearance of Moro’s reflex –

 

Opening of hands (28 weeks) and Extension & Abduction of upper limbs (32 weeks) and followed by Adduction of upper limbs 37 weeks.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 141.

choices.text: Administer IV bicarbonate
Initiate bag-and-mask ventilation
Intubate with an endotracheal tube
Initiate chest compressions immediately

questions.text: A term male neonate, born to a 22-year-old primigravida mother via vaginal delivery, exhibits immediate postnatal cyanosis, respiratory distress, and a scaphoid abdomen. On physical examination, the heart sounds are notably heard on the right side, and there is diminished breath sound on the left side of the chest. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most appropriate initial step in the resuscitation of this newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intubate with an endotracheal tube

 

Option C: 

 

The case describes diaphragmatic hernia. As a result of herniated bowel contents into the chest, these children often have pulmonary hypoplasia.

 

Bag-and-mask ventilation will cause accumulation of bowel gas (which is located in the chest) and further respiratory compromise. Therefore, endotracheal intubation is the best course of action.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IV bicarbonate cannot be used in this case, As the initial management is to maintain the airway.

 

Option B: Bag-and-mask ventilation is contraindicated in case of diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Option D: The initial management is to secure the airway followed by initiating the chest compressions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia - The management of CDH is required to provide early, appropriate respiratory support. In the delivery room, infants with respiratory distress should be rapidly stabilized with endotracheal intubation. Prolonged mask ventilation in the delivery room, which enlarges the stomach and small bowel and thus makes oxygenation more difficult, must be avoided and a naso- or orogastric tube placed immediately for decompression. Gentle ventilation with permissive hypercapnia reduces lung injury, need for ECMO, and mortality. Factors that contribute to pulmonary hypertension (hypoxia, acidosis, hypothermia) should be avoided.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131; Nelson 21st edition pg 4063

questions.text: A term infant, delivered vaginally following an uneventful pregnancy, presents with an unusual pattern of respiratory distress. The healthcare team observes that the infant appears well and pink while crying, but exhibits significant respiratory distress and becomes dusky when not crying. This pattern suggests a specific type of airway obstruction that is relieved by crying. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choanal atresia

 

Option A: Choanal atresia

 

Choanal atresia is identified by passing a feeding tube through each nostril or by identification of mist on cold metal held under the infant’s nose. Should choanal atresia be diagnosed, endotracheal intubation bypasses the airway obstruction until surgical repair can be completed.

 

Infants are obligate nose breathers

 

When crying they can breathe through their mouth, but they must have a patent nose when quiet.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Diaphragmatic hernia: This condition involves the abnormal protrusion of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity through an opening in the diaphragm. It typically presents with severe respiratory distress shortly after birth due to lung compression but is not characterized by the specific pattern of distress improving with crying.

 

Option C. Meconium aspiration: This occurs when a newborn inhales a mixture of meconium and amniotic fluid into the lungs around the time of delivery, which can lead to breathing difficulties. The respiratory distress associated with meconium aspiration is not typically relieved by crying.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax in a newborn is an accumulation of air in the pleural space, which can lead to collapsed lung and respiratory distress. Like the other conditions listed, the symptoms of pneumothorax are not relieved by crying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of choanal atresia - the distinctive pattern of respiratory distress that is temporarily relieved by crying. Prompt diagnosis and management of this congenital condition, which requires immediate intervention to establish a secure airway for the affected infant.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Continue ventilation for 30 sec more
Continue ventilation for 60 sec more
Intubate and start ventilation

questions.text: Upon arrival in the operating theater, you are immediately briefed on a 1-minute-old neonate who has experienced apnea and has been receiving bag and mask ventilation for the past 30 seconds. Your initial assessment reveals a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and observable spontaneous breathing efforts by the neonate. Given this clinical scenario, what is the most appropriate course of action to take for this neonate's management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discontinue ventilation

 

Option D: 

 

The neonate's current status, with a heart rate above 100 beats per minute and the presence of spontaneous breathing efforts, suggests adequate cardiovascular and respiratory recovery. The primary goal of bag and mask ventilation in neonatal resuscitation is to stabilize the heart rate and ensure effective breathing. A heart rate above 100 beats per minute and visible respiratory efforts indicate that these goals have been achieved, making it appropriate to discontinue assisted ventilation and closely monitor the neonate's spontaneous breathing and overall clinical status.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Continue ventilation for 30 sec more & B. Continue ventilation for 60 sec more: Continuing bag and mask ventilation might be considered if the neonate was still showing signs of respiratory distress or had a heart rate below 100 beats per minute. In this scenario, however, with the neonate demonstrating spontaneous breathing and an adequate heart rate, continued positive pressure ventilation is unnecessary and could potentially be harmful.

 

Option C. Intubate and start ventilation: Intubation and mechanical ventilation are indicated for neonates who do not respond adequately to initial resuscitation efforts, including bag and mask ventilation, or those with specific conditions requiring advanced airway management. Given the neonate's improved condition, this intervention is not warranted at this time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per NRP guidelines, heart rate above 100 per min and spontaneous breathing efforts are an indication to stop ventilation and give post resuscitation care.

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 129-131.

choices.text: Meconium aspiration syndrome
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
All of the above

questions.text: On your first day in the pediatric department, the consulting physician decides to test your knowledge with a series of questions. You confidently answer most of them until you're presented with a particularly challenging one regarding neonatal resuscitation. The question is about identifying the absolute contraindication for using bag and mask ventilation. Which of the following conditions is considered an absolute contraindication for the application of bag and mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Option C: 

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is considered an absolute contraindication for bag and mask ventilation. In cases of CDH, positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the displacement of abdominal organs into the thoracic cavity through the diaphragmatic defect, further compromising lung function and reducing effective ventilation. This can lead to increased pulmonary hypertension and worsening of the patient's condition. Therefore, careful intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation are recommended to manage these neonates, avoiding the use of bag and mask ventilation which could exacerbate the herniation of abdominal contents into the chest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tracheoesophageal fistula: While bag and mask ventilation can be challenging in neonates with a tracheoesophageal fistula due to the risk of gastric distension and potential worsening of respiratory distress, it is not considered an absolute contraindication. These neonates require careful airway management, often with early intubation to secure the airway and prevent complications.

 

Option B. Meconium aspiration: In cases of meconium aspiration syndrome, the initial steps of resuscitation might include suctioning of the airways before ventilation. However, bag and mask ventilation is not absolutely contraindicated and may be necessary if the baby is not breathing effectively after initial clearing of the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is an absolute Contraindication for bag and mask ventilation

 

Ref- O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 130.

choices.text: A4 B3 C1 D2
A4 B1 C3 D2
A3 B2 C1 D2
A3 B1 C4 D2

questions.text: Match the following cardiological conditions in children with their typical chest X-ray findings.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A4 B3 C1 D2

 

Option A:

 

  • Coarctation of Aorta - Typically associated with 'Figure of 3' appearance due to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and post-stenotic dilation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) - Often associated with a 'Snowman' or 'Figure of 8' appearance due to the vertical vein and dilated supracardiac chambers.

 

Option C. Transposition of Great Arteries - The 'Egg on a String' appearance is classically associated with this condition due to the narrow mediastinum and the enlarged cardiac silhouette.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot - 'Coeur en sabot' or boot-shaped heart appearance due to right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 2751

choices.text: Coarctation of Aorta
Bicuspid Aortic Valve
Both A and B
Transposition of Great Arteries

questions.text:
