A 17-year-old presents to the pediatric clinic with her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's lack of menstrual development. The patient has otherwise normal female secondary sexual characteristics. On physical examination, the paediatrician notes a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, a shield-shaped chest, and a shortened fourth metacarpal. An ultrasound examination reveals an infantile uterus and streak ovaries. Subsequent karyotype analysis shows a 45, XO genotype, confirming a diagnosis of Turner syndrome. Considering the various congenital anomalies associated with Turner syndrome, the paediatrician seeks to identify potential cardiac abnormalities that may be present.

Which of the following is NOT a typical cardiac manifestation of Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transposition of Great Arteries

 

Option D:

 

Turner syndrome is associated with specific congenital heart defects, the most common being coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve. Transposition of the great arteries, where the position of the two main arteries going out of the heart is switched, is not commonly associated with Turner syndrome. This congenital heart defect is more typically seen in conditions like congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries (ccTGA) or D-transposition of the great arteries (D-TGA).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Ultrasound pelvis reveals hypoplastic uterus and streak ovaries.
  • Karyotype is indicated in all cases of Turner’s syndrome to exclude presence of Y chromosome (associated with high risk of gonadoblastoma).
  • Echocardiography and ultrasound for kidney for screening of cardiac and renal abnormalities.

 

Management: GH therapy (0.1-0.15unit/kg/day)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coarctation of Aorta - This is a narrowing of the aorta commonly seen in patients with Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Bicuspid Aortic Valve - This involves having two cusps in the aortic valve instead of the normal three and is another common cardiac defect in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome:

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Short stature
  • Shield chest
  • Webbed neck
  • Widely spread nipples
  • Short fourth metacarpal

 

Associated anomalies:

 

  • CVS: coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Renal: horseshoe kidney
  • Gonads: gonadal dysgenesis, gonadoblastoma.
  • Strabismus
  • Cataract

 

Ref: Essential pediatrics by OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 637 & TGA, Page No. 540-543

choices.text: Transposition of Great Arteries
Trilogy of Fallot
Tetralogy of Fallot
Atrioventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic by an anxious mother due to concerns about delayed developmental milestones. The pediatrician notes the child has features consistent with intellectual disability, including difficulty with age-appropriate problem-solving and communication tasks. Additionally, the child has distinctive physical characteristics such as a short neck, brachycephaly, and a sandal gap between the first and second toes. Examination of the eyes reveals Brushfield spots - whitish spots on the periphery of the iris. Karyotyping confirms a diagnosis of Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome. Given the diagnosis, the pediatrician considers the potential for congenital heart disease, which is common in children with Down syndrome. What is the most common congenital heart disease associated with Trisomy 21?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD)

 

Option D:


Children with Trisomy 21 are at a higher risk for congenital heart defects, with the most common being an atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD). This condition involves a combination of anomalies that result in a large hole between the chambers of the heart and abnormalities of the valves that regulate blood flow between the chambers. This can cause a significant shunting of blood and lead to heart failure if not corrected.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Transposition of Great Arteries - This is a condition where the main arteries are reversed. It is not the most common heart defect associated with Down syndrome.

 

Option B. Trilogy of Fallot – it is not associated with down syndrome.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot - While this can occur in children with Down syndrome, it is less common than AVSD in this population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common congenital heart disease in case of Down's syndrome is Endocardial Cushion defects (AVSD).

 

The clinical features of Downs syndrome (trisomy 21) are:

 

  • Flat facial profile and an upward slant to the eye
  • Short neck
  • Abnormally shaped ears
  • White spots on the iris of the eye (Brushfield spots)
  • Single, deep transverse crease on the palm of the hand
  • Brachycephaly
  • Protruding tongue
  • Presenile Alzheimer’s disease

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No. 610-615

choices.text: Atrial Septal Defect
Ventricular Septal Defect
Mitral Valve Prolapse

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy with complaints of joint pain and backache. The mother reports a history of hypermobility and frequent dislocations of his shoulders and knees. She also mentions the family history of heart problems in her Husband. Upon further examination, a lens dislocation is identified. A diagnosis of a Fibrillin protein defect was identified. What is the most common cardiac condition that can be seen in this boy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitral Valve Prolapse

 

Option C:


Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, and it is known to have several cardiovascular manifestations due to the weakness in the connective tissue. Mitral valve prolapse is the most common cardiac condition seen in individuals with Marfan syndrome. It occurs due to the enlargement and redundancy of the mitral valve leaflets, which can lead to mitral regurgitation.

 

  • Patients have to be managed with regular echocardiography to detect if cardiac surgery is required.

 

  • The operations can be delayed by the use of ß-blocker medication or angiotensin receptor-2 blockers, to keep the blood pressure as low as reasonable. Neonatal Marfan syndrome is particularly severe.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial Septal Defect - While atrial septal defects can be a part of the spectrum of congenital heart diseases, they are not specifically associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Option B. Ventricular Septal Defect - Similar to atrial septal defects, VSDs are not the most common cardiac manifestation in Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis - This condition involves narrowing of the mitral valve and is not typically associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome:

 

Heart defects includes:

 

  • Aortic root dilatation (may rupture in later teenage life)
  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Mitral regurgitation

 

Associated defects:

 

  • FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15, or TGFBR2 mutation
  • Dural ectasia
  • High arched palate
  • Arm-span greater than height
  • Hypermobility
  • Lens dislocation (Superolateral)
  • Pectus excavatum

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No. 618-619 and 644-645

choices.text: Cardiac failure
Eisenmenger Syndrome
Infective Endocarditis
All of the above

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician by their mother. The chief complaints are easy fatigability and failure to thrive, with a known history of acyanotic heart disease. During the physical examination, the physician notes a holosystolic murmur. Subsequent echocardiography reveals a large ventricular septal defect (VSD). Considering the diagnosis, which of the following is a potential complication of a large VSD in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

Option D:

 

All of the above mentioned are the complications of VSD.

 

  1. Cardiac failure- In a heart with a medium or large VSD, the heart works harder and the lungs have too much blood pumped to them. Without treatment, heart failure can develop.
  2. Eisenmenger syndrome- An unrepaired hole in the heart can lead to this complication after many years. Irregular blood flow causes the blood vessels in the lungs to become stiff and narrow. Blood pressure rises in the lungs' arteries (pulmonary hypertension). This syndrome permanently damages the blood vessels in the lungs.
  3. Endocarditis- This is a rare complication of VSD. An infection causes life-threatening inflammation of the inner lining of the heart's chambers and valves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is a congenital anomaly characterized by an opening in the ventricular septum which can vary in location and size. Clinically, most cases (80-90%) are asymptomatic, with some presenting a pansystolic murmur and possible thrill at the left lower sternal edge. Complications include cardiac failure, Eisenmenger Syndrome, and infective endocarditis.

 

ECG may show biventricular hypertrophy by 2 months, and chest X-rays in large defects can display increased pulmonary markings and cardiomegaly.

 

Management depends on the defect's size, with small VSDs often closing spontaneously and large ones requiring medical therapy and possible surgical intervention by 3-5 months.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 404-412

choices.text: Knee Chest Position
Intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate

questions.text: A mother arrives at the emergency department with her 4-year-old child who has a history of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). The child is currently experiencing a cyanotic spell. In managing this acute situation, which of the following interventions is not typically utilized for the treatment of cyanotic spells in a child with TOF?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium chloride

 

Option D:
 

Cyanotic spells or "Tet spells" in Tetralogy of Fallot are acute episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia caused by a sudden increase in right-to-left shunting through the ventricular septal defect, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow. The knee-chest position is used to increase systemic vascular resistance, which can help redirect blood flow to the lungs. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate may be administered to correct metabolic acidosis, which can result from hypoxia. Humidified oxygen is given to increase the oxygen content of the blood that is being shunted to the systemic circulation.

 

Calcium chloride, however, is not a standard treatment for cyanotic spells in TOF. It is generally used in situations of hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia, or calcium channel blocker overdose and does not have a direct role in the acute management of a cyanotic spell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Knee-Chest Position: Increases systemic vascular resistance and redirects blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option B. Intravenous Sodium Bicarbonate: Corrects the metabolic acidosis that can accompany hypoxia.

 

Option C. Humidified Oxygen: Increases the oxygen content in the blood, thus helping to alleviate hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is no role of Calcium chloride in management of cyanotic spell in TOF.

 

Management strategies for cyanotic spell in TOF include:

 

  • Humidified O2
  • Knee-chest position
  • Intravenous sodium bicarbonate 1 meq/kg
  • SC Morphine 0.1 mg/kg
  • Propranolol/metoprolol
  • Phenylephrine
  • Severe cases: Ketamine, Intubation and ventilation
  • Emergency palliative surgery in refractory cases

 

Ref: O P Ghai 8th Edition, Page no. 417 to 420.

choices.text: Clubbing of fingers and toes
Wide pulse pressure
Fixed split S2

questions.text: During a routine check-up for a 15-day-old male infant, the clinician auscultates a continuous machinery-like murmur at the left upper sternal border. Aside from the murmur, the infant appears to be normal. An echocardiogram is performed and confirms the diagnosis of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Among the following options, which is a common clinical feature associated with PDA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Wide pulse pressure

 

Option C:

 

Patent ductus arteriosus is characterized by a persistent connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. This connection leads to a continuous flow of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery throughout the cardiac cycle, which can result in a bounding pulse due to the increased pulse pressure. The increased volume load on the left side of the heart can cause a wide pulse pressure, which is the difference between the systolic and diastolic blood pressure.

 

Note - The continuous machinery-like murmur heard on physical examination is also characteristic of PDA.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyanosis: Cyanosis is generally not a feature of PDA unless there is a reversal of blood flow due to pulmonary hypertension (Eisenmenger syndrome), which is rare in early life.

 

Option B. Clubbing of fingers and toes: Clubbing is typically a late feature of congenital heart disease with cyanosis and is unlikely to be present in a 15-day-old infant with PDA.

 

Option D. Fixed split S2: A fixed split S2 is commonly associated with atrial septal defect, not PDA. The continuous flow in PDA does not affect the splitting of S2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent ductus arteriosus (PDA) typically remains open beyond one month after the expected birth date. Clinically, most cases are asymptomatic, but a characteristic continuous murmur may be heard in the left infraclavicular area. ECGs are usually normal unless the PDA is large, in which case it may show signs of left ventricular volume loading. Chest X-rays remain normal generally, but a large PDA can cause increased pulmonary vascular markings. Management involves catheter-based closure at 1 year or surgical ligation between 1-3 months for large defects.Top of Form

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 404-405

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text: Somu, a term infant with no prior health issues, is brought to the emergency department on day 3 of life due to the sudden onset of respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals feeble pulses in the lower limbs. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. For the immediate stabilization of this infant, which of the following management options should be initiated first?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prostaglandin therapy

 

Option C:

 

Prostaglandin therapy, specifically Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1), is the initial management choice for infants with coarctation of the aorta presenting with critical symptoms. Prostaglandin E1 helps to keep the ductus arteriosus open, ensuring adequate systemic blood flow in conditions like coarctation of the aorta, where the narrowed segment can significantly impede blood flow to the lower part of the body. This therapy can stabilize the infant hemodynamically until further definitive interventions can be performed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not as an initial stabilizing therapy in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option B. Furosemide: A diuretic used to reduce fluid overload but not the first-line immediate treatment for coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option D. Racemic Epinephrine: Typically used for acute upper airway obstruction (e.g., croup) and not for stabilization in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The importance of Prostaglandin E1 therapy in the immediate management of infants with coarctation of the aorta presenting with critical symptoms, is for maintaining ductal patency and ensuring systemic perfusion until definitive corrective measures.

 

Note - Surgery or catheterization techniques provide definitive repair for the coarctation of the aorta.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No. 428-429.

questions.text: A 4 days old newborn came with abnormal staring look for more than one minute. On further evaluation baby was diagnosed with neonatal seizure. what is the drug of choice in neonatal seizure?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Phenobarbitone

questions.text: Match the following most common conditions in children and their Organisms responsible for it:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A4 B3 C1 D2

 

Option B:

 

  1. Acute epiglottitis, often presenting with fever, dysphagia, drooling, and distress, is most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b.

  2. Croup, characterized by a "barking" cough, stridor, and hoarseness, is frequently caused by the Parainfluenza virus.

  3. RSV is the leading cause of bronchiolitis in children, characterized by wheezing and difficulty breathing.

  4. Atypical pneumonia, often presenting with a more gradual onset of cough and fever, can be caused by Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st  Edition page 8773

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.
